article.description: Antoine McGee wanted badly to get a teammate off the hook.
article.headline: CU's Harrison notches 21 and 15
article.linkText: Buffs blow big bulge, beat Sooners in OT
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Antoine McGee wanted badly to get a teammate off the hook. "I felt a lot of frustration for Michel Morandais," McGee said. "So I had to go in and make up for it." McGee scored seven of 10 points in overtime and David Harrison had 21 points and 15 rebounds to lead Colorado to a 94-87 victory over Oklahoma Wednesday night. Blair Wilson had 18 points and Morandais added 14 for Colorado (16-8, 8-5 Big 12 Conference). It was Harrison's 11th double-double as the Buffaloes won their third straight game. Leading by one in the last 30 seconds of regulation, a pass from McGee never reached Morandais. Jason Detrick, who had 35 points for Oklahoma (16-8, 6-7 Big 12 Conference), stole the pass and then converted both free throws. Colorado sent the game into overtime with a free throw with two seconds left before McGee took over at the start of the second period. "That's the kind of player Antoine is," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said. "He gives us a third quality point guard." Jaison Williams had 16 points and Lawrence McKenzie and Drew Lavender 11 each for the Sooners, who dropped their third in a row. "Heart. Unbelievable," Oklahoma coach Kelvin Sampson said of Detrick. "He is one senior who plays with a big heart." McGee scored the first five points as Colorado pulled ahead 82-77 before the Sooners scored on two free throws by Detrick 90 seconds into overtime. Oklahoma managed only four free throws over the next two minutes while McGee sank another free throw and Wilson buried a 3-pointer. Glenn Eddy sealed the win with a layup and free throw with 1:33 left. Colorado led by as much as 60-43 after a 3-pointer and basket by Marcus Hall with 9:53 left in regulation. "We knew they could come back and warned the team about Oklahoma being a battle-tested team," Patton said. "It didn't help us that we had some inopportune turnovers and took some ill-advised shots down the stretch." The Buffs closed the first half with a 15-3 run to take a 41-36 lead. Oklahoma, which was 8-for-13 on 3-pointers, led 33-26 after Lawrence buried a 3-pointer with 4:28 left. Wilson's reverse layup, a 3-point play by Eddy, and McGee's jumper tied the game at 33. Morandais and Harrison accounted for three points as the Buffaloes were 7-for-8 shooting in the run that ended with a 3-pointer by Oklahoma's Drew Lavender.
